snippet: Officials in Saudi Arabia and Qatar said they were withholding heavier weapons in part because of worries by the United States that they could end up in the hands of terrorists.
abstract: Officials in Saudi Arabia and Qatar say they are refusing to provide Syria's rebels with heavier weapons in part because they have been discouraged by the United States, which fears the heavier weapons could end up in the hands of terrorists; Saudis and Qataris say they hope to convince their Western allies that such risks could be overcome.

byline.contributor: Michael R. Gordon contributed reporting from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Officials in Saudi Arabia and Qatar said they were withholding heavier weapons in part because of worries by the United States that they could end up in the hands of terrorists.

headline.seo: Citing U.S. Fears, Arab Allies Limit Aid to Syrian Rebels
headline.main: Citing U.S. Fears, Arab Allies Limit Syrian Rebel Aid
headline.print_headline: Citing U.S. Fears, Arab Allies Limit Syrian Rebel Aid
